PERSONAL STATEMENT â€” Step-by-Step Template

ðŸ“Œ What is it?
A personal statement tells your story â€” who you are, what drives you, and why you deserve this opportunity. It's your chance to go beyond grades and show the real YOU.

ðŸ“ Structure (750-1000 words):

ðŸ”¹ Paragraph 1: THE HOOK (100-150 words)
â€¢ Start with a compelling moment, story, or experience
â€¢ Make the reader want to know more
â€¢ Example: "At 14, I wrote my first program to help my mother track sales at her market stall in Accra..."
â€¢ AVOID: "I am writing to apply for...", "My name is...", dictionary definitions

ðŸ”¹ Paragraph 2: ACADEMIC JOURNEY (150-200 words)
â€¢ Your key academic achievements and interests
â€¢ What sparked your passion for this field
â€¢ Relevant coursework, projects, or competitions
â€¢ Show intellectual curiosity, not just good grades

ðŸ”¹ Paragraph 3: EXPERIENCE & IMPACT (150-200 words)
â€¢ Research, internships, work experience, volunteering
â€¢ What you DID, what you LEARNED, what IMPACT you made
â€¢ Use specific numbers: "organized 5 workshops reaching 200 students"
â€¢ Connect experiences to your academic goals

ðŸ”¹ Paragraph 4: WHY THIS PROGRAM (100-150 words)
â€¢ Be SPECIFIC about the university/program
â€¢ Mention professors, labs, courses, or resources
â€¢ Show you've done your research
â€¢ Explain how this program uniquely fits your goals

ðŸ”¹ Paragraph 5: FUTURE VISION (100-150 words)
â€¢ Clear career goals (short-term and long-term)
â€¢ How this degree leads to those goals
â€¢ What impact you want to make in your community/country
â€¢ End with a strong, memorable closing statement

ðŸ’¡ Golden Rules:
âœ… Show, don't tell (use examples)
âœ… Be specific and personal
âœ… Connect past â†’ present â†’ future
âœ… Every sentence should add value
âœ… Proofread at least 5 times
âœ… Get 3 people to review it

sop.title: ðŸ“‹ Statement of Purpose (SOP) Structure
sop.content:
STATEMENT OF PURPOSE â€” Section-by-Section Guide

ðŸ“Œ What is it?
An SOP is more academic and research-focused than a personal statement. It emphasizes your intellectual trajectory and research readiness.

ðŸ“ Structure (1000-1500 words):

ðŸ”¹ Section 1: INTRODUCTION (150 words)
â€¢ Your broad area of interest
â€¢ What motivates your research curiosity
â€¢ A brief overview of your academic path
â€¢ Hook: Start with an interesting observation or question in your field

ðŸ”¹ Section 2: ACADEMIC BACKGROUND (250-300 words)
â€¢ Relevant courses and how they shaped your thinking
â€¢ Academic projects and their outcomes
â€¢ Thesis work (if applicable)
â€¢ Skills gained: programming languages, tools, methodologies
â€¢ Academic achievements and awards

ðŸ”¹ Section 3: RESEARCH EXPERIENCE (250-300 words)
â€¢ Describe each research experience in detail
â€¢ What was the problem? What did you do? What were the results?
â€¢ Publications or presentations (if any)
â€¢ What you learned about conducting research
â€¢ How it shaped your research interests

ðŸ”¹ Section 4: PROFESSIONAL EXPERIENCE (150-200 words)
â€¢ Work experience relevant to your field
â€¢ Technical skills developed
â€¢ Leadership or teamwork examples
â€¢ How work experience complements your academic goals

ðŸ”¹ Section 5: RESEARCH INTERESTS & GOALS (200-250 words)
â€¢ Specific research questions you want to explore
â€¢ Why these questions matter
â€¢ Methodology you'd like to use
â€¢ Potential impact of your research
â€¢ Name specific professors you'd like to work with

ðŸ”¹ Section 6: WHY THIS UNIVERSITY (100-150 words)
â€¢ Specific faculty members and their research
â€¢ Labs, centers, or facilities
â€¢ Courses or specializations unique to this program
â€¢ Culture, location, or collaboration opportunities

ðŸ”¹ Section 7: FUTURE PLANS (100 words)
â€¢ Short-term: What you'll do with the degree
â€¢ Long-term: Your vision for your career
â€¢ How you'll contribute to your field/community

ðŸ’¡ SOP vs Personal Statement:
â€¢ SOP = More academic, research-focused
â€¢ Personal Statement = More personal, story-driven
â€¢ When in doubt, check what the program asks for
â€¢ Some programs use the terms interchangeably

cv_format.content:
ACADEMIC CV â€” Template for Scholarship Applications

ðŸ“Œ Why it matters:
Your CV is often the first document reviewers see. A clean, well-organized CV makes a strong first impression.

ðŸ“ Sections (in order):

1ï¸âƒ£ CONTACT INFORMATION
â€¢ Full name (larger font)
â€¢ Email (professional â€” not coolboy99@...)
â€¢ Phone number with country code
â€¢ LinkedIn profile (if complete)
â€¢ GitHub/portfolio (if applicable)
â€¢ Location: City, Country

2ï¸âƒ£ EDUCATION
â€¢ Degree, University, Country (Year - Year)
â€¢ GPA/CGPA (if above 3.0 / Second Class Upper)
â€¢ Relevant coursework (3-5 courses)
â€¢ Thesis title (if applicable)
â€¢ Awards/honors

3ï¸âƒ£ RESEARCH EXPERIENCE
â€¢ Project title, institution, dates
â€¢ 2-3 bullet points: what you did and what resulted
â€¢ Include supervisor name

4ï¸âƒ£ WORK EXPERIENCE
â€¢ Position, Company, dates
â€¢ 2-3 bullet points with action verbs
â€¢ Quantify impact where possible

5ï¸âƒ£ PUBLICATIONS & PRESENTATIONS
â€¢ Use proper citation format
â€¢ Include conferences, workshops, posters
â€¢ "Submitted" or "In preparation" is okay

6ï¸âƒ£ SKILLS
â€¢ Programming: Python, Java, C++, etc.
â€¢ Tools: TensorFlow, Git, LaTeX, etc.
â€¢ Languages: English (Fluent), French (Basic), etc.

7ï¸âƒ£ LEADERSHIP & VOLUNTEERING
â€¢ Position, Organization, dates
â€¢ 1-2 bullet points on impact

8ï¸âƒ£ AWARDS & HONORS
â€¢ Award name, organization, year
â€¢ Brief description if not self-explanatory

9ï¸âƒ£ REFERENCES
â€¢ 2-3 references with name, title, institution, email
â€¢ Or write: "Available upon request"

ðŸ“ Formatting Rules:
âœ… 1-2 pages (undergrad), 2-3 pages (graduate)
âœ… Consistent font (11-12pt, serif or sans-serif)
âœ… Clear headings and sections
âœ… Reverse chronological order
âœ… Save as PDF (never Word)
âœ… No photos (unless specifically required)
âœ… No personal details like age, religion, marital status
âŒ No fancy colors, graphics, or borders
âŒ No first person ("I" â€” use bullet points instead)
âŒ No gaps in timeline without explanation

activity_list.title: ðŸ“‘ Activity List â€” How to Write Compelling Descriptions
activity_list.content:
ACTIVITY LIST â€” Making Your Experiences Shine

ðŸ“Œ What is it?
Many applications (especially US universities and some scholarships) ask for an activity list â€” a structured summary of your extracurricular activities, work, and achievements.

ðŸ“ For each activity, include:
â€¢ Activity name
â€¢ Your role/position
â€¢ Organization
â€¢ Duration (hours/week and total weeks/year)
â€¢ Brief description (150 characters for US apps, or 50-100 words for others)

ðŸ”‘ The Formula for Great Descriptions:
ACTION VERB + WHAT YOU DID + IMPACT/RESULT

âŒ Bad: "Member of coding club"
âœ… Good: "Led weekly Python workshops for 30 students, increasing club membership by 50% and launching 5 student projects"

âŒ Bad: "Volunteered at hospital"
âœ… Good: "Coordinated health education program reaching 200+ patients monthly; trained 15 new volunteers"

ðŸ“‹ Categories to include:

1. ACADEMIC ACTIVITIES
â€¢ Research projects, science fairs, academic competitions
â€¢ Study groups you organized
â€¢ Academic publications or presentations

2. LEADERSHIP
â€¢ Student government, club president
â€¢ Team captain, project leader
â€¢ Mentoring or tutoring

3. COMMUNITY SERVICE
â€¢ Volunteer work, NGO involvement
â€¢ Community projects, fundraising
â€¢ Teaching or outreach

4. WORK EXPERIENCE
â€¢ Part-time jobs, internships
â€¢ Freelancing, entrepreneurship
â€¢ Family business responsibilities

5. CREATIVE & PERSONAL
â€¢ Arts, music, writing
â€¢ Sports, athletics
â€¢ Personal projects, blogs, YouTube

ðŸ’¡ Tips:
âœ… Quality over quantity (5 deep involvements > 15 surface-level)
âœ… Show progression (member â†’ leader)
âœ… Quantify everything (numbers make impact concrete)
âœ… Prioritize: Most impactful activities first
âœ… Be honest â€” embellishing backfires
âœ… Include informal activities too (self-study, family responsibilities)

dos_and_donts.title: ðŸ’¡ Essay Dos and Don'ts â€” Common Mistakes and Fixes
dos_and_donts.content:
ESSAY DOS AND DON'TS â€” Avoid These Mistakes!

âœ… DO:

1. START STRONG
â€¢ Hook the reader in the first sentence
â€¢ Use a story, question, or vivid scene
â€¢ Make them want to read more

2. BE SPECIFIC
â€¢ âŒ "I'm passionate about AI"
â€¢ âœ… "Building a crop disease detection model for Ghanaian farmers showed me AI's power to transform agriculture"

3. SHOW, DON'T TELL
â€¢ âŒ "I am a hard worker"
â€¢ âœ… "I balanced a full course load while working 20 hours weekly and maintaining a 3.8 GPA"

4. ANSWER THE QUESTION
â€¢ Read the prompt 5 times before writing
â€¢ Every paragraph should connect to the prompt
â€¢ Don't go off on tangents

5. USE ACTIVE VOICE
â€¢ âŒ "The project was led by me"
â€¢ âœ… "I led the project"

6. PROOFREAD OBSESSIVELY
â€¢ Read aloud â€” you'll catch errors your eyes miss
â€¢ Use Grammarly (free version is fine)
â€¢ Have 3 different people review
â€¢ Wait 24 hours between writing and editing

7. BE AUTHENTIC
â€¢ Your real story is more compelling than fiction
â€¢ Vulnerability is strength
â€¢ Show self-awareness and growth

âŒ DON'T:

1. DON'T USE CLICHÃ‰S
â€¢ "Since childhood I have always..."
â€¢ "In today's rapidly changing world..."
â€¢ "I believe education is the key to success"
â€¢ "Webster's dictionary defines..."

2. DON'T REPEAT YOUR CV
â€¢ Your essay should tell a STORY, not list achievements
â€¢ Add context, emotions, and lessons learned

3. DON'T BE GENERIC
â€¢ If you could swap in any university name, it's too generic
â€¢ Research the specific program

4. DON'T USE BIG WORDS TO SOUND SMART
â€¢ Simple, clear writing > complicated vocabulary
â€¢ Short sentences are powerful

5. DON'T EXCEED THE WORD LIMIT
â€¢ If they say 500 words, stay at 480-500
â€¢ Going over shows you can't follow instructions

6. DON'T MAKE EXCUSES
â€¢ Address challenges positively
â€¢ Focus on what you learned and how you grew

7. DON'T SUBMIT FIRST DRAFTS
â€¢ Good essays need 5-10 revisions minimum
â€¢ The best essays are rewritten, not written

ðŸ”„ Revision Checklist:
â–¡ Does it answer the prompt?
â–¡ Is the opening compelling?
â–¡ Are there specific examples?
â–¡ Does every paragraph add value?
â–¡ Is the voice authentically mine?
â–¡ Is it within the word limit?
â–¡ Have 3 people reviewed it?
â–¡ Is it error-free?
